natural problem: Add $10_7 + 163_7.$ Express your answer in base 7.
natural solution: We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a = of_nat (10) in base 7"
and h1 : "b = of_nat (163) in base 7"
shows  "a + b = of_nat (203) in base 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $10_7 + 163_7.$ Express your answer in base 7. The final Answer is 203_7
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.
 We get $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 0_7 \\ + & 1 & 6 & 3_7 \\ \cline{2-4} & 2 & 0 & 3_7, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{203_7}$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a = of_nat (10) in base 7"
and h1 : "b = of_nat (163) in base 7"
shows  "a + b = of_nat (203) in base 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In base 7, add the numbers 10 and 163. The final answer is 203 (in base 7).

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat_of_base 7 "
and h1 : ""
and h2 : "b = nat_of_base 7 "
and h3 : ""
shows  "base_of_nat 7 (a + b) = "203""
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.
 We get $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 0_7 \\ + & 1 & 6 & 3_7 \\ \cline{2-4} & 2 & 0 & 3_7, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{203_7}$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat_of_base 7 "
and h1 : ""
and h2 : "b = nat_of_base 7 "
and h3 : ""
shows  "base_of_nat 7 (a + b) = "203""
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If we consider a and b as numbers with base 7, find the sum of a and b in base 7. The result should be 203.

assumes h0 : "a = (nat_of_diglist [1, 0])"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 Num.One)))"
and h1 : "b = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One)))))"
shows  "a + b = numeral (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One))))"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $10_7 + 163_7.$ Express your answer in base 7. The final Answer is 203_7
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.
 We get $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 0_7 \\ + & 1 & 6 & 3_7 \\ \cline{2-4} & 2 & 0 & 3_7, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{203_7}$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 Num.One)))"
and h1 : "b = numeral (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit1 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One)))))"
shows  "a + b = numeral (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One))))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

The result is the natural number represented by "numeral (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit0 (Num.Bit1 Num.One))))".

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
and h1 : "b = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc 0))))), Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
shows  "c = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0] + nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc 0))))), Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $10_7 + 163_7.$ Express your answer in base 7. The final Answer is 203_7
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.
 We get $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 0_7 \\ + & 1 & 6 & 3_7 \\ \cline{2-4} & 2 & 0 & 3_7, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{203_7}$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
and h1 : "b = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc 0))))), Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
shows  "c = nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0] + nat_of_rev7 [Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc (Suc 0))))), Suc (Suc (Suc 0)), Suc 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given two numbers where the first number is 3 and the second number is 6, find the sum of these two numbers. The final answer is represented as a variable c.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = nat_of_septenary (septenary_of_nat 10)"
and h1 : "y = nat_of_septenary (septenary_of_nat 163)"
shows  "septenary_of_nat (x + y) = septenary_of_nat 203"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $10_7 + 163_7.$ Express your answer in base 7. The final Answer is 203_7
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, in the second column we get $1+6=7$, which we carry just as in base 10 by placing the digit 0 in the sum and carrying 1 to the next column.
 We get $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 0_7 \\ + & 1 & 6 & 3_7 \\ \cline{2-4} & 2 & 0 & 3_7, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{203_7}$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = nat_of_septenary (septenary_of_nat 10)"
and h1 : "y = nat_of_septenary (septenary_of_nat 163)"
shows  "septenary_of_nat (x + y) = septenary_of_nat 203"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If $x$ is the natural number equivalent of the septenary (base 7) representation of the natural number 10 and $y$ is the natural number equivalent of the septenary representation of the natural number 163, find the septenary representation of the natural number that is the sum of $x$ and $y$. The final answer is the septenary representation of the natural number 203.
